topics.topic_name: Introduction to Electricity and Its Uses

concepts.summary: Electricity is used in many areas of daily life such as cooking, lighting, transportation, heating and cooling, entertainment, communication, and more.
concepts.details: Examples include electric kettles, fans, trains, mobile phones, and computers. Electricity can be grouped in different ways based on its application.

concepts.summary: Electricity is generated from various sources like windmills, solar panels, falling water (hydroelectric), and fossil fuels like coal and gas.
concepts.details: The electricity reaches our homes via wires. For safe learning, only batteries or cells should be used in experiments, not main power supply.

concepts.summary: A torch contains a lamp, a switch, and electric cells inside. The lamp glows when the switch is in one position and stops when switched off.
concepts.details: Opening a torch reveals cells that provide the electrical energy. The switch controls the flow of electricity to the lamp.

concepts.summary: An electric cell is a portable source of electrical energy with two terminals: positive (+) and negative (-).
concepts.details: The metal cap is the positive terminal and the flat metal disc is the negative terminal.

concepts.summary: A battery is a combination of two or more cells connected together. The positive terminal of one cell connects to the negative terminal of the next.
concepts.details: A battery provides more energy or longer duration than a single cell. The term 'battery' is sometimes used for a single cell too.

concepts.summary: An incandescent lamp has a thin wire called a filament inside a glass bulb. When current passes, the filament gets hot and glows.
concepts.details: The filament is connected to two thicker wires which are the lamp's terminals. They connect to the metal case and the metal tip at the base.

concepts.summary: An LED (Light Emitting Diode) lamp does not have a filament. It has two terminals: a longer wire (positive) and a shorter wire (negative).
concepts.details: LEDs glow only when current passes in one direction: positive terminal to positive of battery, negative to negative.

concepts.summary: A lamp glows when its terminals are connected to the corresponding terminals of a cell or battery, forming a complete circuit.
concepts.details: The lamp glows only in arrangements where there is a complete path for current. Incandescent lamps work regardless of polarity; LEDs require correct polarity.
examples: Connecting lamp to cell with wires

concepts.summary: An electrical circuit is a complete path that allows electric current to flow from the positive terminal to the negative terminal of a cell.
concepts.details: Current flows through the filament of an incandescent lamp, making it glow. A broken filament (fused bulb) stops the current.

concepts.summary: A switch is a device that completes or breaks a circuit, turning a device ON or OFF.
concepts.details: In ON position, the switch closes the gap and allows current to flow. In OFF position, the gap is open and current stops.

concepts.summary: Electrical components are represented by standard symbols. A drawing of a circuit using these symbols is called a circuit diagram.
concepts.details: Symbols include those for cell, battery, lamp, LED, switch (ON/OFF), and wire. Standard symbols help people worldwide understand circuits.
examples: Symbol for cell: long line (+), short line (-)
Symbol for LED: triangle with arrows

concepts.summary: Materials that allow electric current to flow easily are called conductors. Metals like copper, silver, and gold are good conductors.
concepts.details: Copper is commonly used for wires due to good conductivity and lower cost. Conductors are used in wires, switches, plugs, and sockets.

concepts.summary: Materials that do not allow electric current to pass are called insulators. Examples are plastic, rubber, glass, and wood.
concepts.details: Insulators are used to cover wires, plugs, and switches to prevent electric shocks and ensure safety.

concepts.summary: Our body is a conductor of electricity. Electric current can cause severe injury or death. Always handle electrical devices with care.
concepts.details: Never touch switches with wet hands, avoid using devices in wet areas, and do not use damaged equipment. Use only batteries for experiments.

concepts.summary: Batteries provide Direct Current (DC) used for small devices. Power plants provide Alternating Current (AC) used for larger appliances at home.
concepts.details: DC flows in one direction; AC changes direction periodically. Wall sockets supply AC.
